title: Half-life - Bi-212 decays to Tl-208 and Po-208

content.question: Bismuth-<math alttext="212" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>212</mn></math> has a half-life of about <math alttext="60" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>60</mn></math> minutes. It decays and becomes thallium-<math alttext="208" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>208</mn></math> in 36% of the cases and polonium-<math alttext="208" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>208</mn></math> in 64% of the cases. Thallium-<math alttext="208" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>208</mn></math> has a half-life of <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> minutes and decays to become the stable isotope lead-<math alttext="208" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>208</mn></math>. Polonium-<math alttext="208" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>208</mn></math> has a half-life of <math alttext="299" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>299</mn></math> nanoseconds and also decays to lead-<math alttext="208" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>208</mn></math>. Consider a sample of bismuth atoms. After <math alttext="60" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>60</mn></math> minutes, which of the following claims about the sample is correct?

choices.label: The total mass is about half of the original mass.

The number of lead-<math alttext="208" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>208</mn></math> atoms is close to half of the original number of bismuth-<math alttext="212" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>212</mn></math> atoms.
The sample is almost entirely comprised of lead-<math alttext="208" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>208</mn></math>.

The atoms in the sample are 50% bismuth-<math alttext="212" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>212</mn></math>, 18% thallium-<math alttext="208" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>208</mn></math>, and 32% polonium-<math alttext="208" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>208</mn></math>.

content.answer: The number of lead-<math alttext="208" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>208</mn></math> atoms is close to half of the original number of bismuth-<math alttext="212" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>212</mn></math> atoms.

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
